projects.name: Playing with Paper
projects.finished_product_description: This book explores the art of papercraft, featuring illuminated, engineered, and reimagined paper art.

diagram_descriptions: Top left: A small, light orange, folded paper ornament on a pink patterned background.
Top middle: A red, folded paper star ornament.
Top right: An orange and a yellow folded paper star ornament against a green background.

Middle section: The title 'PLAYING WITH PAPER' in large black sans-serif font, followed by the subtitle 'ILLUMINATING, ENGINEERING, AND REIMAGINING PAPER ART' in smaller red serif font, enclosed by decorative brackets. Below this is the author's name 'HELEN HIEBERT' in black serif font.
Bottom left: A red folded paper screen or divider with cut-out leaf shapes, revealing a textured white paper behind it.
Bottom right: A close-up of a paper sculpture resembling succulent leaves, with painted textures in shades of yellow, orange, and green.

projects.name: Felt Notebook Covers

steps.instruction: Cut two pieces of felt to approximately 4x6 inches. One piece will be the cover, the other will be the inner pages.
steps.visual_description: Two rectangular pieces of felt, one orange and one green.

steps.instruction: Fold the orange felt piece in half to create the cover. Stitch along the folded edge to secure.
steps.visual_description: Orange felt folded in half, with dashed stitching lines along the fold.

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of white cardstock to approximately 2x3 inches and a piece of teal felt to approximately 1.5x2 inches.
steps.visual_description: A white rectangular cardstock piece and a smaller teal rectangular felt piece.

steps.instruction: Adhere the white cardstock and teal felt onto the front of the orange felt cover, as shown.
steps.visual_description: The orange felt cover with the white cardstock and teal felt attached in the center, slightly overlapping.

steps.instruction: Insert the green felt pages into the orange cover and stitch around the edges to bind.
steps.visual_description: The orange cover with the green felt pages inside, stitched along the outer edges.

projects.finished_product_description: A small, handmade notebook with a decorative felt cover.

projects.name: Paper Cutout Necklace Pendant

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of red cardstock to approximately 2x3 inches.
steps.visual_description: A red rectangular piece of cardstock.

steps.instruction: Using a craft knife, carefully cut out the geometric pattern from the center of the cardstock.
steps.visual_description: The red cardstock with a diamond-shaped geometric cutout in the center.

steps.instruction: Punch a small hole at the top center of the cardstock cutout.
steps.visual_description: The red cutout with a hole at the top.

steps.instruction: Thread the necklace chain through the hole.
steps.visual_description: The red cutout hanging from the gold necklace chain.

steps.instruction: String beads and the silver bell onto the chain below the pendant, securing them with knots or crimps.
steps.visual_description: The necklace chain with red beads and a silver bell attached below the red paper pendant.

projects.finished_product_description: A unique necklace featuring a red paper cutout pendant with beads and a small bell.

projects.name: Paper Cake Slice

steps.instruction: Cut and assemble white and cream cardstock to form a triangular cake slice shape with layers.
steps.visual_description: A three-dimensional slice of cake made from white and cream cardstock, with a white scalloped edge representing frosting.

steps.instruction: Attach a candle to the top of the cake slice.
steps.visual_description: A small candle with a yellow flame and silver base is inserted into the top of the paper cake slice.

steps.instruction: Place the paper cake slice onto a small paper plate with a floral print.
steps.visual_description: The paper cake slice is positioned on a white paper plate decorated with colorful flowers.

steps.instruction: Place a small paper fork next to the cake slice on the plate.
steps.visual_description: A small white paper fork rests on the paper plate beside the cake slice.

projects.finished_product_description: A miniature, decorative paper slice of cake, complete with a candle, on a floral paper plate.

projects.name: Collage Card

steps.instruction: Cut and fold a piece of beige patterned cardstock to create a card base.
steps.visual_description: A beige cardstock base with a vintage script pattern.

steps.instruction: Cut various pieces of scrapbook paper with vintage text and floral designs.
steps.visual_description: Several small pieces of paper with different vintage patterns.

steps.instruction: Arrange and adhere the scrapbook paper pieces onto the card front to create a layered collage effect.
steps.visual_description: The card front is covered with overlapping pieces of patterned paper, creating a collage.

steps.instruction: Add a large yellow letter 'L' sticker to the collage.
steps.visual_description: A yellow letter 'L' sticker is placed on top of the collage on the card front.

projects.finished_product_description: A handmade card with a vintage-inspired collage design featuring text, floral elements, and a prominent letter 'L'.

diagram_descriptions: A collage of four images. The top left shows two small handmade notebooks, one orange with a teal and white pocket, and another brown and green stacked behind it. The bottom left shows a red paper cutout pendant with a geometric design, suspended in a small cardboard box, with beads and a bell attached to a gold chain. projects.name: Geometric Paper Sculpture

steps.instruction: Cut the 12x12 inch cardstock into four 6x6 inch squares.
steps.visual_description: A 12x12 inch square divided into four 6x6 inch squares.

steps.instruction: On each 6x6 inch square, draw diagonal lines from corner to corner. Score along these lines.
steps.visual_description: A 6x6 inch square with two dashed lines forming an 'X' from corner to corner.

steps.instruction: Cut along one of the scored diagonal lines on each square, stopping at the center point.
steps.visual_description: A 6x6 inch square with a cut from one corner to the center, along a diagonal line.

steps.instruction: Fold the two flaps created by the cut inwards, forming a triangular shape. Glue the flaps together.
steps.visual_description: A 6x6 inch square with two triangular flaps folded inwards and glued, creating a cone-like shape.

steps.instruction: Repeat steps 2-4 for the remaining three 6x6 inch squares.
steps.visual_description: Four identical cone-like shapes made from squares.

steps.instruction: Arrange the four cone shapes so their open bases form a square. Glue the sides of the cones together to form a pyramid-like structure.
steps.visual_description: Four cone shapes arranged with their open ends forming a square, and their pointed ends meeting at the top.

steps.instruction: Cut small squares from the remaining cardstock and glue them to the open base of the structure to close it.
steps.visual_description: The pyramid-like structure with its base covered by small squares.

tips: Ensure cuts are precise for a neat finish.
Use a light hand with the glue to avoid warping the cardstock.
projects.finished_product_description: A geometric paper sculpture with a layered, faceted appearance, resembling a diamond or a stylized crystal.

tools_reference.name: Craft Knife
tools_reference.use: Cutting paper, especially thicker papers. Requires a #11 blade.

tools_reference.name: Cutting Mat
tools_reference.use: Protects work surface, provides grid for measuring and cutting straight lines.

tools_reference.name: Paper Cutter
tools_reference.use: Cutting small sheets of paper to size.

tools_reference.name: Scissors
tools_reference.use: Cutting paper, including intricate cuts. Assortment of sizes: standard 8 inch (20 cm), child-size, tiny, and heavy-duty.

tools_reference.name: Rotary Tool
tools_reference.use: Cutting fabric, organic lines and shapes.

tools_reference.name: Awl or Potter's Needle
tools_reference.notes: Can be made by poking a needle into a cork.

tools_reference.name: Handheld Hole Punches
tools_reference.use: Punching shapes and holes close to the edge of paper.

tools_reference.name: Japanese Hole Punch
tools_reference.use: Punching holes anywhere on a sheet, with interchangeable punches in various sizes.

tools_reference.name: Circle Cutter
tools_reference.notes: Requires a steady hand and frequent blade changes; must be used on a cutting mat.

tools_reference.name: Metal Rulers
tools_reference.notes: Preferred over plastic rulers as they don't fray. Available in lengths from 6 to 36 inches (15 to 91 cm). Have cork backing to prevent slipping. Transparent graph rulers are useful for plotting lines.

tools_reference.name: Bone Folder
tools_reference.use: Scoring paper in preparation for folding and creasing folds.
tools_reference.notes: Typically made from bone, plastic, or Teflon.

tools_reference.name: Knife
tools_reference.notes: Can use the back of a knife.

tools_reference.name: PVA Glue
tools_reference.use: Adhesive for paper crafts. White, clear-drying, archival.

tools_reference.name: Double-sided Tape
tools_reference.use: Laminating sheets of paper together, temporary connections.
tools_reference.notes: Thin and works well for laminating. Artist's tape is repositionable and leaves no residue.

projects.name: How to Fold a Perfect Sixteen-Section Accordion

tools.name: bench hook or strip of wood

steps.instruction: Place the sheet of paper, face down, on the work surface and fold it in half, matching up the short edges as perfectly as possible. Turn the folded paper to position the folded edge at the top of the work surface (A).
steps.visual_description: A yellow sheet of paper is folded in half with the folded edge at the top of the work surface. This is labeled as (A).

steps.instruction: Take the top leaf (a single layer) of paper and fold it up, matching it up with the top folded edge. Crease the fold. Flip the paper over and repeat with the top leaf of paper on the other side. There are now four layers of paper.
steps.visual_description: A yellow paper is shown folded into an accordion shape with wooden dowels along the top edges. This is labeled as (B).

steps.instruction: Unfold the paper gently and note that there is a valley fold (when unfolded, the fold looks like the letter “V,” or a valley) in between two mountain folds (when unfolded, the fold looks like a mountain ridge) (B). Reverse the valley fold so that there are three mountain folds. Now fold the top mountain fold up to meet the single leaf edge of the sheet, aligning the edges and creasing the new fold. Fold the middle and last folds up in the same manner, aligning all of the edges and creasing each fold (c).
steps.visual_description: A close-up of hands folding a yellow paper accordion with a wooden dowel along the top edge. This is labeled as (C).

tips: Make sure the grain direction runs in the direction of the accordion folds.
Use a bench hook tool to push the edges of the folds up against a firm guide for accuracy; alternatively, you can attach a strip of wood to your work surface.
projects.finished_product_description: A sixteen-section accordion fold.

tools_reference.name: Bench hook or strip of wood
tools_reference.use: To use as a firm guide for accuracy when folding.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram (A) shows a yellow sheet of paper folded in half with the folded edge at the top.
Diagram (B) shows a yellow paper folded into an accordion shape with wooden dowels along the top edges.

projects.name: How to Set an Eyelet

steps.instruction: Punch a hole in the paper where the eyelet will be set.
Place an eyelet face down on a cutting mat, line up the hole in the paper, and set the eyelet setter on top of the straight sides of the eyelet.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a cutting mat with a yellow paper, an eyelet, and an eyelet setter.

steps.instruction: Hammer the back of the eyelet setter with a few short taps to set the eyelet.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a hammer hitting an eyelet setter on top of an eyelet.

tips: Use screw punch for clean holes

projects.name: Stretch It - Diagonal Fold Technique

steps.instruction: Fold a square of paper in half on the diagonal. Fold it in half again.
steps.visual_description: A square of paper folded into a triangle, then folded again into a smaller triangle.

steps.instruction: Cut slits from alternating ends, taking care to cut from the folded edges.
steps.visual_description: A folded paper triangle with parallel slits cut from the folded edge towards the open edge.

steps.instruction: Unfold the paper, hold it from the smallest square, and let gravity take care of the rest.
steps.visual_description: A paper structure that expands into a 3D shape with geometric cutouts.

steps.instruction: Attach a piece of string to hang it, if desired.
steps.visual_description: The 3D paper structure with a string attached for hanging.

projects.finished_product_description: A 3D geometric paper sculpture that hangs.

projects.name: Stretch It - Accordion Fold Technique

materials.item: square or rectangular sheet of paper

steps.instruction: Accordion fold a square or rectangular sheet of paper into four panels (see page 16 for instructions on how to fold an accordion).
steps.visual_description: A sheet of paper folded back and forth into four equal panels.

steps.instruction: Cut alternating slits as indicated.
steps.visual_description: An accordion-folded paper strip with alternating slits cut into the panels.

steps.instruction: Carefully unfold the sheet, and stretch it into three dimensions.
steps.visual_description: A paper structure that expands into a 3D lattice-like form.

projects.finished_product_description: A 3D paper sculpture with a lattice or honeycomb-like structure.

projects.name: Textured Surfaces

steps.instruction: Cut slits of varying shapes and sizes into a sheet of paper.
steps.visual_description: Three images showing different types of cuts on paper: one with star-shaped cuts on red paper, one with vertical slits on light blue paper, and one with alternating short and long vertical slits on light blue paper.

tips: Patterns are available from lamp craft suppliers, or you can design your own.
projects.finished_product_description: Textured paper surfaces created by cutting slits.

projects.name: Slits Across a Fold

steps.instruction: Fold a rectangular sheet of paper in half.
steps.visual_description: A yellow rectangular strip of paper with dashed lines indicating where to cut slits.

steps.instruction: With the open edge facing up on the work surface, fold the top layer of paper back down about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm).
steps.visual_description: The yellow strip of paper from the previous step, now with a folded edge at the top.

steps.instruction: Flip the paper over and repeat on the other side.
steps.visual_description: The yellow strip of paper, now folded on both sides.

steps.instruction: Unfold the last two folds and cut slits perpendicular to and through the center fold at about 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) intervals.
steps.visual_description: A light blue rectangular strip of paper with parallel slits cut perpendicular to the center fold.

steps.instruction: Unfold and roll the form into a cylinder.
steps.visual_description: A light blue paper lantern shape formed by rolling a sheet of paper with slits into a cylinder.

steps.instruction: Adhere the outer edges with a strip of double-sided tape.
steps.visual_description: A light purple paper lantern with angled slits, showing its three-dimensional form.

tips: Try variations using deckled scissors, cutting the folds at an angle, creating additional folds in a taller sheet of paper, or punching decorative holes in each slit.
projects.finished_product_description: A paper lantern or vessel created by cutting slits across a fold.

projects.name: Scored Curves

steps.instruction: Use a compass to draw a series of circles, one inside the other, with approximately 2 inches (5 cm) between each circle.
steps.visual_description: A light pink sheet of paper with concentric circles drawn on it, with two radial lines extending from the center to the outermost circle.

steps.instruction: Score along the plotted lines (freehand or with the aid of a template or French curve).
steps.visual_description: The same light pink sheet of paper as in step 1, but now with scored lines following the drawn circles.

steps.instruction: Remove a small pie-shaped section, as shown.
steps.visual_description: A light pink paper form that has had a small wedge removed, creating an opening. The form is beginning to take a circular, slightly three-dimensional shape.

steps.instruction: Carefully crease along each scored line, alternating mountain and valley folds.
steps.visual_description: A light pink paper form showing alternating mountain and valley folds along the scored lines, creating a layered, circular effect.

steps.instruction: Overlap the edges by 1⁄2 an inch (1.3 cm) and glue or tape in place.
steps.visual_description: A finished light pink paper form, appearing as a rounded, slightly hexagonal shape with layered concentric sections.

steps.instruction: Score a rectangular sheet of paper as shown. Carefully manipulate along the creases to create alternating mountain and valley folds.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular sheet of pink paper with several wavy horizontal score lines. The paper is shown being manipulated into alternating mountain and valley folds.

steps.instruction: Score the curves as shown. Manipulate the creases into mountain folds, bringing the form into a round. Overlay the edges and glue or tape in place.
steps.visual_description: A piece of turquoise paper with several curved score lines. The paper is shown being folded and manipulated into a rounded, vase-like shape. Another image shows the finished turquoise form, which has a distinct hourglass shape with a wider top and bottom and a narrower middle, with the curved folds clearly visible.

tips: Paper choice is important: look for a stiff yet pliable material; otherwise, the paper will tend to crack along the score lines and pucker around the curves.
projects.finished_product_description: A layered, circular paper form and a rounded, vase-like paper form.

projects.name: Pleat Pleat! (Pleated Triangle)

steps.instruction: Fold an isosceles triangle in half and then reverse the fold (folding the paper in both directions is called a universal fold and trains the paper to reverse fold easily in future steps).
steps.visual_description: An isosceles triangle with a central crease line, then reversed to show the universal fold.

steps.instruction: Accordion fold the doubled paper as shown, unfold, and accordion fold again in the other direction, reversing all the folds.
steps.visual_description: The paper is accordion folded, then unfolded, then re-folded in the opposite direction. This corresponds to the crease pattern shown in the top diagram and the resulting pleats in the bottom diagram.

steps.instruction: Unfold completely, holding the tip of the triangle pointing away from you.
steps.visual_description: A completely unfolded isosceles triangle, revealing all the crease lines from the previous accordion folds.

steps.instruction: The first fold on the left half of the triangle is a mountain fold and the center crease is a valley fold.
steps.visual_description: An unfolded triangle with specific crease lines identified as a mountain fold on the left half and a valley fold at the center.

steps.instruction: Carefully reverse all the folds on the right half of the triangle, so they match the folds on the left; at the same time, alternate the short folds in the center crease.
steps.visual_description: The final pleated isosceles triangle, where folds on the right half mirror those on the left, and short folds in the center crease are alternated, resulting in the textured appearance shown in the bottom diagram.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The instructions detail the process of folding an isosceles triangle to create a pleated pattern, involving universal folds, accordion folds, and specific mountain/valley fold reversals to achieve a symmetrical, textured design.

projects.finished_product_description: A paper isosceles triangle with a series of accordion pleats, creating a textured, three-dimensional ridged surface.

diagram_descriptions: The top diagram shows an isosceles triangle made of yellow paper, laid flat. Its surface is marked with numerous parallel lines, some in red and some in black, which converge towards the apex of the triangle. These lines indicate the intended fold lines for the pleating process.

The bottom diagram displays the same isosceles triangle, now partially folded into accordion pleats. The yellow paper forms distinct raised ridges and recessed valleys, creating a textured, three-dimensional effect. The pleats are more pronounced towards the base of the triangle, following the pattern suggested by the lines in the first diagram.

projects.name: Accordion Folded Paper

steps.instruction: Accordion fold a rectangular sheet into eight sections.
steps.visual_description: A green paper folded into multiple vertical pleats.

steps.instruction: Fold the entire accordion in the middle at a right angle and then reverse that fold.
steps.visual_description: A green paper folded in half at a right angle, showing the accordion folds.

steps.instruction: Unfold back to a rectangle and notice the diagonal folds. Work the folds so that the diagonals all end up creasing in the same direction and the verticals alternate between mountain and valley folds.
steps.visual_description: A green paper unfolded to show a pattern of diagonal and vertical folds, with alternating mountain and valley folds.

steps.instruction: Accordion fold a 10 x 16 inch (25.4 x 40.6 cm) sheet of paper into sixteen sections.
steps.visual_description: A green paper folded into many narrow vertical pleats.

steps.instruction: Divide and mark the accordion-folded paper into five 2 inch (5 cm) sections.
steps.visual_description: A long, accordion-folded paper strip with vertical marks dividing it into five sections.

steps.instruction: Score alternating diagonals between the sections.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the accordion-folded paper showing scored diagonal lines between sections.

steps.instruction: Fold along the score lines and then reverse the folds.
steps.visual_description: The accordion-folded paper with diagonal folds made along the score lines.

steps.instruction: Gently unfold to reveal the diamond pattern along the accordion folds.
steps.visual_description: An orange paper showing a pattern of diamond shapes formed by the folds.

steps.instruction: Starting from one end, manipulate the paper into a series of diamonds with convex creases (valley folds) in the center of each diamond.
steps.visual_description: An orange paper object that has been manipulated into a spherical shape with diamond facets.

tips: This fold is best tested first with a thin paper.
Because the paper is thin, it should not be difficult to fold through the layers.
If your paper is wide enough, it can be pulled into a spherical form.
projects.finished_product_description: A paper object that can be manipulated into a spherical form with diamond facets.

projects.name: Window Star
tips: Kite paper is a colored wax paper, traditionally used in European kite making.
Multicolored packages of 6¼ × 6¼ inch (15.9 × 15.9 cm) sheets can be found online or in Waldorf school stores.
Grocery store wax paper or colored tissue are also options, but the crispness and translucency of the kite paper make it worth the special order.
projects.finished_product_description: A star-shaped ornament made from folded paper, with a translucent orange and white pattern.

diagram_descriptions: A large, orange, translucent, star-shaped ornament with twelve points, made from folded paper. The background is a soft-focus green, suggesting foliage.

projects.name: Window Stars

steps.instruction: Fold eight 6 1/4 x 6 1/4 inch (15.9 x 15.9 cm) sheets of kite paper in half, and cut or tear along the folds to create sixteen rectangles that are approximately 6 1/4 x 3 1/8 inches (15.9 x 7.9 cm).
steps.visual_description: Image (A) shows four orange paper rectangles, two of which are folded in half, and two are in a diamond/kite shape.

steps.instruction: Do the following to all sixteen pieces of paper: First, fold the sheet in half lengthwise. Unfold, and then fold all four corners into the center line, creasing the folds and locking them in place with a fingernail or bone folder. Fold all four corners in again. Use a glue stick to tack down all of the folds so that each unit lies flat.
steps.visual_description: Image (A) shows the progression of folding a single piece of paper into a flat, diamond-like shape.

steps.instruction: Take two sections and place one on top of the other. Holding the two narrow points together, fan them apart until the overlap is approximately 1/2 an inch (1.3 cm) and glue the sections together. Continue joining section by section. Apply glue to the last section and tuck it underneath the first section to complete the circle. Attach the star to a window with a small piece of transparent tape.
steps.visual_description: Image (B) shows two orange paper sections being joined together at their narrow points, forming a star shape.

tips: Display a grouping to ward off birds trying to fly through a crystal clear window.
projects.finished_product_description: A star-shaped ornament made of folded paper, suitable for hanging in a window.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram (A) shows four orange paper pieces: two rectangular, one folded in half, and two in a diamond/kite shape, illustrating the cutting and folding steps.
Diagram (B) shows two orange paper sections being joined at their narrow points to form a star shape, illustrating the assembly step.

projects.name: Paper Lantern
tips: Use screw punch for clean holes

diagram_descriptions: Diagram A shows a square of yellow paper with a decorative cut-out pattern, a craft knife, a ruler, a teal pen, and a red punch.
Diagram B shows the yellow paper square with the cut-out pattern, now with a piece of brown string threaded through it and attached to a small wooden stick.

projects.name: Shadow Ornament

steps.instruction: Punch the card-weight paper and trim the edges using a ruler, leaving approximately 1/4 inch (6 mm) around the design for the balsa wood frame (A).
steps.visual_description: Diagram A shows a punched and trimmed piece of cardstock with a frame outline.

steps.instruction: Most balsa wood has colored ends and bar codes. If so, trim or sand to remove these. Measure and cut two lengths to fit the cardstock height and another two that are 1/4 inch (6 mm) smaller. Use an awl to pierce a hole in the center of two of the shorter lengths of balsa wood, thread the needle, and attach a loop of thread to the top for hanging and some beads at the bottom, if desired (B).
steps.visual_description: Diagram B shows two lengths of balsa wood with holes pierced in the center, and a needle threaded with decorative thread and beads attached.

steps.instruction: Place the punched cardstock face down on a piece of scrap paper. Apply a small amount of glue to one edge of a longer length of balsa wood, smooth it out, and adhere it to one edge of the paper, using the paper’s edge as a guide. Repeat with the other longer length on the other side. Check that the smaller lengths will fit between the longer ones, sanding the ends down if necessary or shaving them with a craft knife. Glue them in place (C).
steps.visual_description: Diagram C shows the balsa wood frame being glued to the cardstock.

steps.instruction: Cut the translucent paper slightly larger than the cardstock and place it face down on scrap paper. Apply glue to the face of the square of balsa wood pieces, smooth it out, and then stick it down to the translucent paper. Immediately lift the glued ornament to make sure there are no wrinkles in the translucent paper. Place the ornament on a cutting mat with the translucent paper facedown and trim the paper to the outer edges of the balsa wood (D).
steps.visual_description: Diagram D shows the translucent paper being trimmed to the edges of the balsa wood frame.

tips: Most paper punches have a limited reach, so the size of this ornament is limited to how far the punch can reach into the paper. Cutting a design by hand eliminates this challenge.
projects.finished_product_description: A shadow ornament inspired by Japanese shoji screens.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram A shows a punched and trimmed piece of cardstock with a frame outline.
Diagram B shows two lengths of balsa wood with holes pierced in the center, and a needle threaded with decorative thread and beads attached.
Diagram C shows the balsa wood frame being glued to the cardstock.
Diagram D shows the translucent paper being trimmed to the edges of the balsa wood frame.

tips: Use a heavier weight cardstock to ensure these bugs don’t lose their capacity to fly for a long time!

projects.name: Kirigami Mobile

materials.notes: optional, can be purchased at electronics stores or office supply stores

steps.instruction: Enlarge the template found on page 136 to your desired size and print it onto a sheet of cardstock. These samples each fill an 8½ × 11 inch (21.6 × 28 cm) page. With a craft knife and cutting mat, cut out the butterfly outline, the small shapes in the wings, and the slits in the body (A).
steps.visual_description: Image A shows a pink paper butterfly cut out with intricate wing patterns and body slits, lying on a cutting mat with a ruler. A craft knife is also visible.

steps.instruction: Score along all of the score lines as indicated. Fold the butterfly in half and crease the center line with a bone folder. Unfold the wings about halfway and manipulate the score lines along both sides of the body section, making the body pop up. Fold the butterfly in half again to reinforce the body folds (B).
steps.visual_description: Image B shows a pink paper butterfly that has been folded in half along its body, with its wings partially opened to create a 3D effect. The body is creased and popped up.

projects.name: Interchangeable Ring

materials.dimensions: 1 1/2 or 2 inches [3.8 or 5 cm] in diameter
slightly wider than the ring topper diameter

steps.instruction: Cut out seven or eight circles (1 1/2 or 2 inches [3.8 or 5 cm] in diameter) from the vellum (A).
steps.visual_description: A circle labeled (A).

steps.instruction: Fold each circle in half and crease the fold with a bone folder. Unfold and flatten back out into a circle. Don’t turn the paper over (this fold is easy if the first two creases are on the same side of the paper); fold the circle in half again, so that the two ends of the line that were just folded together overlap. Crease this fold, creating a cross on the circle. Unfold. Now turn the paper over and fold the circle in half so that the end points of the two previous folds meet and overlap. Unfold into a circle again, push in at the center of the last fold, and flatten the folds to create a quarter circle (B).
steps.visual_description: A circle with creases forming a cross, and then folded into a quarter circle labeled (B).

steps.instruction: Cut small pieces of double-sided tape (approximately 1/4 x 1/2 inch [6 mm x 1.3 cm]) to adhere the paper sections. Place a piece of tape on one side of a section and adhere another section to it, taking care to line them up. Repeat with each section, making a long snakelike piece. The last section will be joined to the first, bringing the piece into the round (C).
steps.visual_description: A long snakelike piece of folded paper sections, labeled (C).

steps.instruction: Cut a circle of cardstock just a bit wider than the diameter of the ring topper. Apply a thick layer of white glue (do a test first, to make sure the glue dries clear) to the circle and set the ring topper on it. Push the topper down so that it forms a semi-sphere and all of the folded edges touch the glue. Hold in place until the glue sets (or find a small weight to set on top of it as it dries). Let it sit for a few hours. Place a drop of epoxy on the back of the magnet and attach it to the center of the ring topper. Connect the topper to the ring blank (D).
steps.visual_description: A ring topper attached to a cardstock circle, forming a semi-sphere, labeled (D).

tips: Purchase a circle cutter at an art or craft supply store to make cutting a perfect circle a snap.
projects.finished_product_description: An interchangeable ring topper that attaches to a ring blank with a magnet.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram (A) shows a circle being cut from vellum.
Diagram (B) shows a circle being folded to create a quarter circle.
Diagram (C) shows multiple folded paper sections being joined to form a round shape.
Diagram (D) shows the finished ring topper attached to a cardstock circle, with a magnet on the back.

projects.name: Piece of Cake

steps.instruction: Photocopy the template onto cardstock and cut the pieces (A).
steps.visual_description: Image A shows various paper pieces laid out on a blue cutting mat, including a circular base, a rectangular piece for the cake, a small fork shape, and a long thin strip for the candle.

steps.instruction: Score all of the lines on the bottom of the plate with a thin tool, such as the unsharpened edge of a craft knife. Carefully fold the edge of the plate between each triangle to create a fluted edge. Bend the fork handle slightly so that it rests on the edge of the plate (B).
steps.visual_description: Image B shows the components for the cake: a circular plate with scored lines, a small paper fork, a candle, and a green paintbrush. The plate has triangular sections around its edge that are being folded to create a fluted effect. The fork handle is shown bent.

steps.instruction: Score and fold along all of the solid lines. Glue the tip of the cake together, placing the tab on the inside of the slice. Score and fold the top of the cake and glue it in place, with the frosted edges showing on the outside. Score, fold, and glue the line of frosting between the layers onto the cake (B).
steps.visual_description: Image B shows the components for the cake: a circular plate with scored lines, a small paper fork, a candle, and a green paintbrush. The cake pieces are shown partially assembled, with scored lines visible. The frosting line is also visible.

steps.instruction: Starting with the tapered edge of the candle piece, roll the paper around a toothpick and glue it where the end meets the line on the paper. Put a dab of glue on the bottom of the wick and slip it into the candle (B).
steps.visual_description: Image B shows the components for the cake: a circular plate with scored lines, a small paper fork, a candle, and a green paintbrush. The candle piece is shown being rolled around a toothpick. The wick is also visible.

steps.instruction: Glue the bottom of the cake onto the plate, glue the fork in place, and glue the candle on top (C). Let’s eat cake!
steps.visual_description: Image C shows three finished pieces of cake on decorative plates. One piece has a candle with a flame. The pieces are detailed and look like miniature cake slices.

tips: Before assembling, decorate your piece of cake with stickers, markers, or colored pencils.

projects.name: Photo Envelope Book

steps.instruction: Cut out the hinges and windows. Using a craft knife or scissors, cut, remove, and discard the notches and the angles from the ends. The edge of the envelope is now divided into three sections between the notches. With the flap closed, measure, draw, and cut out the window on one envelope to make a template. Use the window template to trace the shape onto all of the other envelopes (keeping the flaps closed) and cut them out (A).
steps.visual_description: Several blue and yellow envelopes are shown. Some have photos inserted into cut-out windows. One envelope is shown with its flap closed, and a window cut out. A pair of scissors and wooden dowels are also visible.

steps.instruction: Fill the pockets. Cut photographs to fit inside of the envelope: the width should be 1⁄2 an inch (1.3 cm) smaller than the width of the envelope and the height should be 1⁄4 inch (6 mm) shorter than the envelope height. Insert two photos, back to back, into the window frames, paying attention to the orientation. Seal the parts of the flap that are not cut away.

Thread the binding. Cut bamboo skewers to the height of the spine using heavy duty scissors. Arrange the photo pages and stack them with the backs (the sides where the flaps show) of the envelopes all facing the same direction. Working from the bottom of the pile to the top, pick up the bottom two envelopes and thread a skewer into the top section of the top envelope, the middle section of the bottom envelope, and then back into the top section of the top envelope. Pick up the third envelope and place it on top of the first two. Thread the skewer in the same fashion. Continue adding pages until they are all joined (B).
steps.visual_description: A close-up view of the binding of the photo envelope book. Multiple bamboo skewers are threaded through the spines of stacked yellow and blue envelopes, holding them together. The detail shows how the skewers pass through different sections of the envelopes.

tips: Baby envelopes are available at specialty paper stores, stationery stores, and online, where all sorts of papers, shapes, colors, and sizes can be found. Create custom photos for this book by printing them onto photo paper and cutting them to size.

projects.name: Envelope with Hinged Sections

steps.instruction: Trace the template onto lightweight cardstock and cut it out. Place the template with the notched side along one edge of the envelope and mark the notches with a pencil. Mark the slight angle at each end of the pattern as well. Flip the template over and repeat on the opposite side of the envelope (B).
steps.visual_description: A red paper template with a leaf-like cutout is placed on a blue cutting mat. The template has notches along one edge. A white strip with markings is also visible. A yellow pencil and a craft knife are on the mat.

steps.instruction: Using a craft knife or scissors, cut, remove, and discard the notches and the angles from the ends. The edge of the envelope is now divided into six sections between the notches.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram B shows a red paper template with a leaf-like cutout and notches, placed on a blue cutting mat. A white ruler-like strip with markings is also visible. A yellow pencil and a craft knife are on the mat, suggesting the process of marking and cutting.

projects.name: Interlocking Envelopes

materials.dimensions: width 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) smaller than envelope, height 1/4 inch (6 mm) shorter than envelope

steps.instruction: Alternating envelope hinges (envelopes 1, 3, and so on) will be cut like this: Keeping the envelope flap closed, place a straightedge or ruler along the points of the V-shaped notches on one side of the envelope, so that it is parallel to the edge. Using a bone folder, carefully score the section between the top of the envelope and the first notch. Skip a section and then carefully score every other section between the notches (c). Flex the scored sections back and forth and then gently pry the edge of the envelope open, reverse the folds, and tuck the scored sections inside the envelope (d). Repeat on the opposite side of the envelope. For alternating envelopes (2, 4, and so on), score and tuck every other section so that the hinges, when joined, will interlock.
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a close-up of an orange paper envelope with V-shaped notches along the edge. A ruler is placed parallel to the edge, aligned with the points of the notches. A bone folder is shown scoring a line between the top of the envelope and the first notch. Image (d) shows the envelope partially opened, with scored sections folded inwards and tucked.

steps.instruction: Cut a sheet of decorative paper to fit inside of the envelope: the width should be 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) smaller than the width of the envelope and the height should be 1⁄4 inch (6 mm) shorter than the envelope height. Slide the paper inside the envelope and seal the parts of the flap that are not cut away.
steps.visual_description: A piece of patterned yellow paper is shown being inserted into an orange envelope with cut-out leaf shapes. The paper is slightly smaller than the envelope opening.

steps.instruction: Thread the bamboo skewers through the alternating hinges and trim the ends using heavy duty scissors (e).
steps.visual_description: Image (e) shows two orange paper envelopes interlocked. Bamboo skewers are threaded through the interlocking hinges. The ends of the skewers are visible, ready to be trimmed.

Image (D) shows the orange paper envelope partially opened, with scored sections folded inwards and tucked.

paper tidbits
Traditional Japanese momigami is a strong, clothlike  
paper that has been coated in starch, dried, and then 
scrunched until the sheet feels like soft chamois and can  
be used like cloth.
Marbling is the art of printing multicolored swirled or stone-
like patterns on paper or fabric. The patterns are formed by 
first floating the colors on the surface of a liquid and then 
laying the paper or fabric on top of the water, allowing it to 
pick up the color.

projects.name: Woven Paper Table Runner with Windows

materials.dimensions: approx. 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide and 2 inches (5 cm) long

steps.instruction: Cut undulating slits running the length of the warp paper. The first slit should start at the left-hand pencil guideline and approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the bottom guideline and run across the warp, stopping at the right-hand pencil guideline. Continue making slits approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart, stopping 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the top guideline. Cut the weft paper into undulating strips that are approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide, taking care to keep the pieces in order for weaving.
steps.visual_description: A blue paper surface with horizontal pencil guidelines. Undulating slits are cut into the paper, running vertically. Strips of patterned paper are shown cut and ready for weaving.

steps.instruction: Erase pencil marks and turn the warp paper face up. Starting from the left or right, weave the first strip of weft paper over and under the warp paper slits. Weave the second strip starting underneath the warp so that the pattern alternates from row to row to create the woven pattern. Repeat this process and continue alternating to complete the weaving. The last piece might be difficult to weave into the remaining slits. If this is the case, trim the long, flat side of the strip to fit before weaving it in.
steps.visual_description: A close-up view of the blue warp paper with patterned weft strips being woven over and under the slits, creating a woven texture. The pattern alternates.

steps.instruction: Use a glue stick to carefully tack the ends of the woven weft pieces to the warp. Flip the table runner over and glue the remaining ends down.
steps.visual_description: Not explicitly shown, but implied to be securing the woven strips.

steps.instruction: Cut a small piece of styrene or chipboard into a triangular shape that is approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) wide and 2 inches (5 cm) long. Slip the mini cutting mat underneath each section of the warp and/or weft paper and use a craft knife to cut out the little windows.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the woven paper with a triangular template being used to cut out small window shapes. A craft knife is shown, along with cut-out pieces of patterned paper and a glue stick on a cutting mat.

projects.name: Inflatable Ball

steps.instruction: Cut four lengths of tracing paper a bit longer than the template and fold them in half lengthwise. Stack these sections together, creating eight layers of paper. Trace the template onto cardstock, cut it out, place it on top of the stack of tracing paper, and trace the template pattern onto the top layer. Using a craft knife or scissors, carefully cut out eight gores (a).
steps.visual_description: Image (a) shows a white leaf-shaped template placed on top of a stack of folded tracing paper, with a craft knife and pencil nearby on a green cutting mat. The tracing paper has a pattern of tree branches.

steps.instruction: Place one gore face down on a piece of newsprint. Starting 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the top point, apply a thin bead of glue (1/8 inch [3 mm]) to one edge of the gore, ending 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the bottom tip. Be sure to get good coverage with the glue (any gaps will lead to holes in the seam and the ball will not inflate). Smooth out the glue with a brush. Place a second gore on top of the first (right side up), lining up the edges and pressing to adhere the seam. Remove the newsprint and discard it. Let the glue set for a few moments (b).
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows two gores being glued together. One gore is face down on newsprint, and glue is being applied to its edge. A second gore is being placed on top, with hands lining up the edges. A small white bottle of glue and a brush are visible.

projects.finished_product_description: A lightweight ball made of paper gores, which can be inflated or filled with material.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram (a) shows a white leaf-shaped template on a green cutting mat, with a stack of folded tracing paper underneath. A craft knife and pencil are also shown.
Diagram (b) shows hands assembling two paper gores. Glue is being applied to the edge of one gore, and a second gore is being placed on top. A bottle of glue and a brush are visible.

projects.name: Paper Ball

steps.instruction: Slip a piece of newsprint in between gores 1 and 2 on the work surface. Just as in step 2, apply glue, but to the opposite side of gore 2. Attach gore 3 (c). Lift the two gores that were just glued and make sure the glue isn’t seeping through to gore 1. Pinch the glued area and move your fingers along the entire seam to ensure adhesion. Remove and discard the newsprint. Slip another piece of newsprint between gores 2 and 3 on the opposite side and glue gore 4 to gore 3. Continue in this fashion until gore 8 has been glued and is at the top of the stack. The stack of gores will look accordion folded. Go back through each accordion, making sure the seams are glued all the way along the edge and that only two gores are glued together. Let the glue dry. After all the sections are glued together, the view from the end of the stack looks like an accordion. Trim approximately 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the top and bottom tips (d).
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows hands holding two pieces of patterned paper, one being glued to the other. Image (d) shows a stack of folded paper pieces that resemble an accordion, with the top and bottom tips trimmed.

steps.instruction: Slide a piece of newsprint underneath gore 1. Leaving gore 1 flat on the table and keeping gore 8 as is on top of the stack, gently fold gores 2 through 7 in half and tuck them inside the two outer gores. Place a 1⁄8 inch (3 mm) bead of glue along the open edge of gore 1 and carefully adhere gore 8 to it (e). Allow the glue to dry.
steps.visual_description: Image (e) shows a stack of folded paper gores with glue applied to the edge of the bottom gore, ready to attach the top gore.

steps.instruction: Cup one of the cut ends in one hand, gently pinching or covering the opening, and blow air into the other end, and then continue to inflate the ball with a blow dryer on the low setting (F).
steps.visual_description: Image (F) shows a hand holding a partially inflated paper ball, with air being blown into one end.

steps.instruction: Gently force the air out of the ball while cupping one end in one hand, so that the other open end is more or less flat. Cut a circle large enough to cover the hole out of tracing paper, apply glue around the edges, and cap the ball with it, applying pressure with a hand from behind. The other end is not capped, so that the ball can be deflated for storage purposes (g).
steps.visual_description: Image (g) shows a hand capping one end of a deflated paper ball with a circular piece of tracing paper.

tips: When applying glue along the edge of a sheet of paper, it is convenient to have a glue applicator. It is also handy to place a piece of newsprint underneath the item being glued. This will catch any glue that slips off of the object being glued and is easy to pick up and discard, preventing glue in unwanted areas.

In order for all of the imagery to appear on the outside of the ball, place gore #1 face down, gore #2 right side up, gore #3 face down, and so on as the sections get glued together. This isn’t necessary if there is no imagery on the ball.

tips: Tissue paper is available in drugstores, art supply stores, and even grocery stores and comes in a variety of colors and patterns.

projects.name: Paper Hot Air Balloon

materials.item: tracing paper or thin Japanese paper
materials.notes: optional, to avoid gluing tissue paper pieces together

tips: Purchase a roll of tracing paper or a thin Japanese paper to avoid gluing together pieces of tissue paper; however, this colorful tissue paper balloon looks really beautiful when flown.
The gore template (see page 139) can be scaled up to create larger balloons, and a quick search on the Internet will lead to a variety of gore patterns for other interesting shapes and sizes.
Find a wide-open space and make note of the wind direction.
Seasoned balloonists release a small rubber helium balloon to test the winds.
Only fly the balloon in light wind (or in a large auditorium for a more controlled flight).
The paper has to be light enough to float when the balloon is filled with hot air.
The air temperature where the balloon is being flown is also a factor.
Good flights require a large temperature difference between the air inside and outside the balloon, so the balloon will fly best on a cool day.
There are also safety considerations. Paper burns, so take care not to get the heat source too close to the paper.
It is best to launch in a big open area or indoors with high ceilings, so the balloon doesn’t get caught in trees or drift toward power lines or roads.
Depending on the temperature and wind conditions, be prepared to chase the balloon for several blocks.

projects.name: Book Jacket with Pocket

steps.instruction: Run both layers of the pocket through an unthreaded sewing machine set on a wide straight stitch, remembering not to pierce the top edge. Then, with the flaps of the jacket folded over, run the top and bottom edges of the book jacket through the sewing machine (b). Alternately, use an awl to pierce holes along the edges of the cover, approximately 1⁄8 inch (3 mm) apart. Set a piece of foam core or Styrofoam beneath the paper for easy punching.
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows a sewing machine needle piercing holes through an orange fabric. The holes are in a straight line, approximately 1/8 inch apart. Image shows the top edge of the fabric being sewn.

steps.instruction: Tie a knot in one end of the thread and cut the end of the thread short. Thread the needle. Starting at one corner of the pocket on the inside of the book, hand stitch through the holes using a running stitch. Remove the double-sided tape from the inside of the pocket. Tie off the thread at the end of the pocket on the inside of the jacket. Tie another knot in the end of the thread and sew the top and bottom edges of the book, knotting the thread at each end (c).
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a needle and light blue thread being used to hand stitch through pre-pierced holes on an orange fabric. The stitching is a running stitch. The image shows the thread knotting off at the end of a seam.

tips: There are a couple of tricks to hiding the knots and tying off the thread on the top and bottom edges of the cover. Tie a knot at the end of the thread and begin stitching at the end hole on the inside of the folded cover (between the two layers of paper). Take the needle from the inside, between the layers, to the outside of the cover (the knot will be held by the paper) and begin the running stitch, continuing across the cover. There will be one rogue hole on the inside of the cover that never has a thread going through it. To end the sewing (because it is hard to tie a knot in between the two layers of paper), backtrack one hole and insert the needle so it just goes through one layer of paper, to the inside, and then create an “S” stitch between the layers of paper and around some of the existing stitches. This will be invisible and will hold like a knot.

T
he cover for this booklet is made from just one sheet of paper. 
Hedi Kyle developed this structure using origami and other folding tech-
niques. The booklet is completed when a simple signature (a stack of paper 
folded in half) is pamphlet stitched into the center of the cover.

projects.name: Folded Paper Envelope

steps.instruction: Reverse fold #2 and bring it up to meet fold #3, forming a pleat. Fold the bottom edge up to meet the pleated fold (c).
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a partially folded paper object with a pleat formed at the bottom edge.

steps.instruction: Fold in the two bottom corners at 45-degree angles, lining them up with the two long vertical folds (d).
steps.visual_description: Image (d) shows the bottom corners of the paper object folded inwards at a 45-degree angle, aligning with vertical fold lines.

steps.instruction: Flip the section of paper (with the folded corners) up toward the top. Fold the bottom two corners (the new ones that were hidden beneath) up at 45-degree angles to meet the horizontal fold line (e).
steps.visual_description: Image (e) shows the paper object flipped, with new bottom corners folded upwards at a 45-degree angle to meet a horizontal fold line.

steps.instruction: Fold the paper back down along that horizontal fold line, covering the bottom corners that were just folded. Fold the long vertical sides into the middle (f).
steps.visual_description: Image (f) shows the paper object folded down along a horizontal line, covering previously folded corners, and the long vertical sides folded towards the center.

steps.instruction: Fold the top corners down at 45-degree angles so that they meet in the center. Fold the bottom edges back up, aligning the top edges (g).
steps.visual_description: Image (g) shows the top corners folded down at a 45-degree angle to meet in the center, and the bottom edges folded up to align with the top edges.

steps.instruction: Take a bone folder and a straightedge and score well along the edge of the last fold, creasing the layer of paper directly beneath the fold (h).
steps.visual_description: Image (h) shows hands using a bone folder and a straightedge to score a fold on the paper object.

tips: The next two steps are tricky!

projects.name: Folded Paper Pocket Folder and Pamphlet

materials.purpose: to place underneath for punching holes

materials.dimensions: three times the height of the cover

steps.instruction: Unfold the last two folds and stick a finger between the two layers of paper. Fold the paper along the crease that was just made and flatten the folds, creating a kite shape. Repeat on the other side.
steps.visual_description: Image (i) shows hands unfolding paper. Image (j) shows a folded paper with a kite shape. Image (l) shows the completed kite shape on the paper.

steps.instruction: Tuck one kite-shaped section into the other. Hold the tucked sections together and tuck them up underneath, creating a triangular top.
steps.visual_description: Image (k) shows one kite-shaped section being tucked into the other. Image (l) shows the tucked sections creating a triangular top.

steps.instruction: Cut four to six sheets of office paper to 4 1/4 x 8 inches (10.8 x 20.3 cm) and stack them together. Fold the stack of pages in half to 4 1/4 x 4 inches (10.8 x 10 cm).
steps.visual_description: Image (m) shows a stack of folded paper pages.

steps.instruction: Set the spine of the folded signature on the fold of the pocket folder. Set a piece of cardboard or Styrofoam underneath and with an awl, punch three holes through the signature and the cover, one in the middle, and one 1/2 an inch (1.3 cm) from each end. Cut a piece of thread three times the height of the cover and thread the needle with it. Following the diagram above, draw the needle through the center hole, starting on the inside of the signature. Bring the needle through the top hole and back to the inside. Skip the center hole and bring the needle out through the bottom hole. Bring the needle back through the center hole and into the inside of the booklet. Tie a knot around the thread running along the spine, and cut the ends to approximately 1/2 an inch (1.3 cm).
steps.visual_description: Image (m) shows the pamphlet being prepared for binding with holes punched. Diagram (n) illustrates the sewing process for binding the pamphlet, showing numbered holes (1, 2, 3, 4) and the path of the needle and thread, starting and finishing points, and a knot. A separate illustration shows the finished knot.

diagram_descriptions: A diagram illustrating the construction of a Sode Kite. It shows the main kite body as a large rectangle with dimensions 24" (70 cm) wide and 28" (71 cm) tall. Several slits are marked: 1/4" (6 mm) slits are located at the top-left and bottom-left corners, and also centered on the bottom and right edges. projects.name: Kite

steps.instruction: Lay the paper out on a work surface. Follow the diagram (see page 85) to draw the kite body and the small triangular piece onto the paper with a pencil. Cut out the pieces using a craft knife and straight-edge. Remember to cut the small slits in the kite body, the two diagonal slits “under the arms” of the kimono, and the two slits on the triangular piece.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the kite body and a small triangular piece to be cut out, with indicated slits.

steps.instruction: Cut the following lengths of bamboo: One vertical spar: 30 1⁄2 inches (77.5 cm) Two horizontal wing spars: 25 inches (63.5 cm) (mark the center on each of the horizontal spars) One bottom skirt spar: 12 inches (30.5 cm)
steps.visual_description: List of bamboo spar lengths to be cut.

tips: During assembly, keep in mind that the kite surface (and spars!) must be symmetric for stable and directional flight. Measurements are given as guides only; skilled kite makers modify traditional designs, being careful to maintain symmetry and structural integrity.

tools_reference.name: Bamboo spars
tools_reference.use: Form the support structure for the kite. They have a “skin side,” which is green and brown, and a “pulp side,” which is light tan.

tools_reference.name: Sail
tools_reference.use: Refers to the paper of the kite.

tools_reference.name: Bridle
tools_reference.use: The line that connects directly to the kite. This rigging holds the kite at its flying angle relative to the wind.

tools_reference.name: Wing
tools_reference.use: The upper portion of the kite where the lift is produced during flight.

diagram_descriptions: Image A shows several pieces of dark fabric or paper with a repeating pattern of hexagonal shapes, each containing a stylized flower. Some flowers are green and white, others are pink and white. One small triangular piece is separate.
Image B shows a close-up of a section of dark fabric or paper with a large, stylized flower design in green, blue, and white, set within a diamond or hexagonal grid pattern.

projects.name: Kite

steps.instruction: Glue the triangular piece onto the top of the kite, centering it and overlapping by 1/2 an inch (1.3 cm). Fold a 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) seam allowance on the two equal sides of the triangle, overlapping the paper at the corner. Glue the seam allowances in place (b).
steps.visual_description: Diagram (b) shows the triangular piece glued to the top of the kite with seam allowances folded and glued.

steps.instruction: Using a sharp pencil and pressing firmly, mark a 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) seam allowance around all the edges of the kite. The pressed-in pencil line will score the seams, enabling them to fold accurately. Fold all of the seam edges up, but do not glue yet.
steps.visual_description: The kite paper has a scored line around its edges, 1/2 inch from the perimeter.

steps.instruction: Lay the vertical spar skin side down, threading the bottom end through the center slit and keeping the top flush with the top of the triangle. Lay the top and bottom wing spars horizontally, with about 1/2 an inch (1.3 cm) of each end extending out through the side slits (c). Lay the bottom horizontal skirt spar along the bottom seam allowance, slipping the ends through the slits. With all four spars in place on the paper, apply a line of glue along the center spine. Flip it over and press it into place, keeping it on the center line. Apply glue to the pulp side of one wing spar and flip it into place, using the seam as a guide. Repeat with the second wing spar. Follow the same procedure for the small skirt spar at the bottom. When all four spars are in place and the glue is dry, apply a bead of glue along all seam allowances and fold the paper snugly over the spars, overlapping the corners (d).
steps.visual_description: Diagram (c) shows spars being threaded through slits. Diagram (d) shows the completed kite with spars glued and paper folded over them.

tips: Itajame (ee-tah-ji-may) is a traditional Japanese fold-and-clamp shibori, or tie-dye, technique. Ideally, thin, strong, absorbent papers are folded in various patterns; the folds are gently held in place with blocks, sticks, or shaped pieces; and the edges and corners of the folded paper stacks are then dipped into colorful, lightfast, wash-fast inks. When opened flat, beautiful patterns emerge.
projects.finished_product_description: A kite constructed from paper with decorative patterns.

diagram_descriptions: Photograph (C) shows a close-up of a partially assembled kite with brushes, glue, and a pencil.
Photograph (D) shows two finished kites with colorful floral patterns and bamboo spars, resting on a cutting mat with scissors and a glue bottle.

projects.name: Kite

steps.instruction: Cut two pieces of cotton line that are slightly longer than the wing spars. Working on the back of the kite with the sail on the table, tie one end of string to the exposed spar end on one side of the top wing spar. Pull the line almost taut and secure the other end to the opposite end of the spar. Do the same with the bottom wing spar and the remaining length of string. The bowlines will be adjusted when preparing the kite for flight (as described in the first bullet of step 10—do not adjust the bowlines until ready to fly).
steps.visual_description: Two kites shown from above, one with green floral patterns and one with pink floral patterns. The kite with green patterns is in the foreground and appears to be the one being worked on. A spool of white thread and blue scissors are visible to the right of the kite. The kite has wooden spars. A label 'E' is visible on the top left of the kite.

steps.instruction: Turn the kite over so that the front side is face up. At the intersections of the horizontal wing spars and the spine (the neck and waist of the kimono shape), use a needle to poke two holes on either side of the spar on the diagonal. Thread one end of the cotton line through the sail from the front side of the kite (the side that will be seen when flown). Then bring the line back through the other hole to the front so that both ends are on the front side of the kite. Make the two ends equal and tie a square knot securely over the spar intersection. Then tie the two free ends together in a simple overhand knot approximately 2 inches (5 cm) from the first knot. Trim the ends.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a kite sail with floral patterns. A white string is being threaded through two small holes on either side of a spar intersection. The string forms a loop. A diagram labeled 'H' shows a close-up of a knot being tied around a horizontal line, with two vertical lines hanging below. The text next to the diagram reads 'Lark's Head Knot'.

projects.finished_product_description: A kite with floral patterns and wooden spars, with bridle loops attached.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram labeled 'E' showing two kites with floral patterns, one in the foreground. A spool of thread and scissors are to the right.
Diagram labeled 'F' showing a close-up of a kite sail with floral patterns.
Diagram labeled 'G' showing a close-up of a kite sail with floral patterns and a string being threaded through holes.
Diagram labeled 'H' showing a close-up of a Lark's Head Knot being tied around a horizontal line, with two vertical lines hanging below.

projects.name: Concertina Book Folding

steps.instruction: Place the folded paper in front of you so that the cut edges are on your right and the folded edges are on your left. Fold the top right corner down, forming a right triangle against the left side of the concertina. Repeat at the bottom of the page, folding the bottom right corner up and forming a right triangle against the left side of the concertina (D).
steps.visual_description: Hands using a bone folder to fold the top right corner of a grid-lined concertina paper down to form a right triangle. The cut edges are on the right and folded edges on the left.

steps.instruction: Open the first page, holding it straight up. This will form a straight vertical plane to fold the next two panels against. Replicating what you did with the first panel, fold the top right corner of the next section down into a right triangle and fold the bottom right corner up to create a right triangle. (Notice that the first and last panels are two thicknesses of paper; all others are four thicknesses.) Work through each set of panels, using the previous panel held vertically to keep your folds square (E).
steps.visual_description: Hands using a bone folder to fold the top right corner of a subsequent section of the grid-lined concertina paper down, similar to step 4, to form a right triangle.

steps.instruction: When you get to the last panel, go through the stack in the other direction, reversing the triangle folds (so they are creased in both directions). Don’t make new folds! Next, unfold all of the triangles and return the concertina panels to their original rectangular shape. (In pop-up lingo, this double creasing is referred to as “exercising the folds.” This preparation will make assembly easier, much like preparatory folds in origami) (F).
steps.visual_description: Hands using a bone folder to reverse a fold on the grid-lined concertina paper, creasing it in the opposite direction.

tips: Use the previous panel held vertically to keep your folds square.
Double creasing (exercising the folds) will make assembly easier, much like preparatory folds in origami.

diagram_descriptions: D: Close-up of hands using a bone folder to fold the top right corner of a grid-lined concertina paper down to form a right triangle.
E: Close-up of hands using a bone folder to fold the top right corner of a subsequent section of the grid-lined concertina paper down, similar to step 4, to form a right triangle.
F: Close-up of hands using a bone folder to reverse a fold on the grid-lined concertina paper, creasing it in the opposite direction.

Bottom-left image: A finished concertina book with fan-like folded pages, some with decorative paper inserts in green and yellow patterns, lying open on a wooden surface. A piece of natural twine and two small rectangular pieces of patterned paper are next to it.

projects.name: The Non-Adhesive Wrap

steps.instruction: Before beginning this step, unfold the entire sheet once more and place it printed side down. The first fold in the center is a mountain fold and the first side panel folds are valley folds. Refold the entire accordion, reversing the center panel folds, so that they are aligned with the side folds and the first fold is a valley fold. Fold the side panels up so that they are at a 90-degree angle to the center (g). What comes next is tricky, so take your time. Looking at the corner of the pleat, you are basically folding each diamond shape into fourths. Find the first diamond (skip the half-diamond at the very end) and fold it in half vertically by bringing the outer left and right points together, training the base and side folds to the inside. Then fold it in half horizontally, reminding the folds to maintain their proper direction. The first and last panels only have half a diamond shape and can simply be pinched together and folded up against the sides of the wrapper (h).
steps.visual_description: A piece of paper folded into an accordion or concertina shape, with the corners being manipulated to form diamond shapes. Image (g) shows the side panels folded up at a 90-degree angle. Image (h) shows the first and last panels pinched together.

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of cover-weight paper to 7 x 17 1/2 inches (17.8 x 44.5 cm). Place the paper on the work surface in a horizontal position, printed side down. Starting at the right edge, mark and score vertical lines at 4, 8 1/4, 9, 13 1/4, and 13 3/4 inches (10, 21, 23, 33.7, and 35 cm). Fold along the score lines (i).
steps.visual_description: A rectangular piece of paper with multiple vertical score lines marked on it. Image (i) shows the paper folded along these score lines, creating a concertina or accordion effect.

steps.instruction: Taper the ends in the 4 inch (10 cm) section if needed and tuck them into the front pocket of the concertina. Use double-sided tape to tack the back edge of the concertina to the cover. Apply four small Velcro dots in the corners to make a closure (j).
steps.visual_description: The concertina-folded paper being attached to a cover, with the ends tapered and tucked. Image (j) shows the final closure with Velcro dots.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold along score lines to create concertina. Taper ends and tuck into front pocket. Attach back edge to cover with double-sided tape. Apply Velcro dots for closure.

tips: It is helpful to notice that the concertina folds on the base and sides will always be in the same direction/orientation. Only on the short portion of the pleat that folds back over itself, along the center line of the diamond shape, is the direction of the fold inverted.
projects.finished_product_description: A clever wraparound cover created by folding and attaching a piece of paper.

} barbara mauriello: book arts
Barbara Mauriello’s academic background in literature and the 
fine arts led her more than thirty years ago to an apprenticeship at  
The Center for Book Arts in New York City, a place where she  
teaches today. In all of her years of teaching and making books, she 
finds herself returning to the same themes: color, form, and the 
transformation of materials. A folded and cut piece of paper becomes a 
landscape of mountains and valleys.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram of a template for a Piano Hinge Album, showing a rectangular strip with three V-shaped notches on one side.

Diagram of a template for an Inflatable Ball, showing a large lens shape with an inner outline representing the actual template shape. Text indicates it's half the template and should be photocopied at 200%.
Diagram of a template for an Envelope Folding Screen, showing a long, narrow strip with a zig-zag edge created by V-shaped notches.

Diagram of a template panel for a Hot Air Balloon, shown as a long, tapered strip with a straight left edge and a zig-zag right edge. Detailed measurements are provided for segments along the length. A note indicates the diagram is at 15% scale and the actual diagram is double the width shown on the left.
A small, elongated oval shape labeled 'Actual template shape' within the Inflatable Ball template diagram.

A large installation piece hanging from the ceiling, composed of many small, circular, white paper elements arranged in a grid pattern across a large white fabric or paper backdrop. The backdrop is suspended by thin wires, and the overall effect is ethereal and delicate. The floor below is dark and reflective, with shadows cast by the installation.

A white, intricate, lace-like dress or sculpture made of paper or textile, standing upright on a wooden floor. The dress is very detailed and appears to be constructed from many small elements. It is surrounded by a large pile of tangled ropes, threads, and other fibrous materials in various colors and textures.

A star-shaped sculpture or book made of folded pinkish-copper colored material. The sculpture has multiple facets, and within each facet, the letters 'A', 'L', 'P', 'H', 'A', 'B', 'E', 'T', 'A' are visible, suggesting it is a folded book or a series of folded pages. The interior of the folds is a deep red color.
